awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The effects of COVID-19 on food choice and well-being
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Crises force people to adjust to novel circumstances in ways known to affect behavior, health, and well-being. Nutritional considerations are a critical component of adjustment to crises as individual and community circumstances change in ways that affect food availability and other costs and benefits relevant to food choice. This is particularly true in the context of COVID-19, which has affected not only personal circumstances (e.g., income), but also food supply chains, costs, and so on. This doctoral dissertation research investigates how people adjust food choice to crisis in the context of the ever-evolving COVID-19 pandemic. It tests anthropological theories of resilience and disaster to investigate whether and how people change dietary habits to alleviate the stresses associated with ongoing crisis. In addition to training a first-generation doctoral student in anthropology, the research will be disseminated widely, including to local communities and stakeholders.

Specifically, this research proposes a biocultural theoretical lens to investigate 1) food access, preferences, and choices; 2) the use of food in response to stress; and 3) the effects of related decisions on human biology and health. The doctoral student will conduct surveys, gather data on food consumption and diet-related activities, and collect biological measurements (hemoglobin levels, height, weight, body fat percentage) to achieve these research aims. The study will be conducted in communities that have been variably affected by COVID-19 in terms of maintenance of personal and household income and community-wide food availability. Findings from this research will provide a broader understanding of how crises change behavior and health via its holistic investigation of food choice as a critical mediator of stress and health outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Employing an engaged, integrative anthropological framework, this research investigated how the COVID-19 pandemic impacted people’s ability to feed themselves and their families, how consumption becomes embodied, and how external, structural factors such as crises affect and inform how people make nutritious choices. This research provides a grounded ethnographic and biocultural example of how people rationalize their choices in protecting their bodies, as well as protecting their families, in order to make sense of the changing sociocultural world around them. In the simplest of terms, we examined food as a way to connect with participants to expand our understanding of how people make sense of, choose, and embody necessary objects, like food, in rapidly changing contexts.

This research contextualizes how people derive meaning from their culturally informed perceptions, preferences, and choices of foods and how these choices become embodied in light of the rapidly changing political, economic, and social constraints of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. This research focused on determining if and how people consciously choose their food in association with their socio-ecological contexts as a form of ethnomedicine that further reshaped the embodiment of their local biologies (Lock 1993) in the context of the COVID-19 crisis. This research expands upon existing scholarship by considering how people derive meaning in a situated context particularly within the confines of an unprecedented pandemic. We conducted this research in Oaxaca, Mexico, a location that has a world-renown local cuisine within a country that experienced one of the world’s highest rates of COVID-19 and with long-standing, very high rates of diet-related diseases. We used methods in cultural (ethnography, free lists, pile sorts, interviews, questionnaires/recalls) and biological (blood samples, anthropometric data) anthropology to understand how people perceived and used foods to protect their bodies, and in turn, how locally-held beliefs of ethnonutrition became embodied, as well as how cultural ideologies on what is considered edible allow people to conceptualize foods in multiple and complicated ways.

This research has contributed to the doctoral training of a first-generation student. The research has broadened training of people from underrepresented groups, including an undergraduate student from the University of Notre Dame and two key informants from Oaxaca by having them participate in participant recruitment, ethnographic data collection, data analysis, and dissemination of results. Co-PI Hurd has worked with a number of undergraduates in the past with her pilot data and recruited a new undergraduate student to assist her with the food frequency data during summer and fall 2022. Hurd trained the student in the necessary anthropological methodologies of the research, which will allow them to use these methodologies to continue collecting qualitative and quantitative health-related data in the future. This project has provided professional development opportunities in attending conferences and will further provide opportunities in publishing in the near future.

Co-PI Hurd has also presented aspects of this work (and the broader field of anthropology) to fifth grade students at a local school near the university. This presentation has allowed for the exposure of anthropology to students that otherwise would not have gotten it until much later (if at all) in their academic career. Co-PI Hurd was able to share basic concepts about diversity and cultural differences in her presentation on food and nutrition via an anthropological lens to this public audience.
